captions.text:
Oh, my god, is that the thing
that's keeping you alive?

It was.
It is now an antique.

This is what will
be keeping me alive
for the foreseeable future.

I'm swapping it up
for an upgraded unit,

And I just ran into
a little speed bump.

Speed bump,
what does that mean?

It's nothing.
It's just a little snag.

There's an exposed wire
under this device.

And it's contacting the
socket wall and causing
a little bit of a short.
It's fine.

What do you want me to do?
Put that on
the table over there.

That is irrelevant.
Oh, my god!

I want you to reach in,
and you're just gonna
gently lift the wire out.

Is it safe?
Yeah, it should be fine.

It's like operation.
You just don't let it touch

The socket wall
or it goes "beep."

What do you mean,
"operation"?

It's just a game,
never mind.

Just gently lift the wire.
Okay? Great.
Okay.

You know,
I don't think that I'm
qualified to do this.

No, you're fine.
You're the most capable,
qualified,

Trustworthy person
I've ever met.
You're gonna do great.

Is it too much of
a problem to ask?
'cause I'm...

Okay, okay.
I really need your help here.
Okay.
Oh, there's pus!

It's not pus.
It's an inorganic plasmic
discharge from the device,

Not from my body.
It smells!
Yeah, it does.
The copper wire.

The copper wire,
you got it?

Okay, I got it! I got it!
Okay, you got it?
Now, don't let it

(buzzing)
touch the sides when
you're coming out!

I'm sorry.
I'm sorry.

That's what
I was trying to
tell you before.

Okay, now make sure
that when you pull
it out, you don't...

There's a magnet
at the end of it!
That was it.

(rapid beeping)
you just pulled it out.

Oh, god!
Okay, I was not expecting...

Don't put it back in!
Don't put it back in!
Okay, what do I do?
What's wrong?

Nothing, I'm just going into
cardiac arrest 'cause you
yanked it out like a trout...

What? You said it was safe!
We gotta hurry.
Take this. Take this.

You gotta switch
it out really quick.
Okay. Okay.

Tony? It's going to be okay.
What?

Is it?
It's gonna be okay.

I'm gonna make this okay.
Let's hope.

Okay, you're gonna attach
that to the base plate.
Make sure you...
(screams)

Was that so hard?
That was fun, right?

Here, I got it.
I got it. Here.
Nice.

Are you okay?
Yeah, I feel great.
You okay?
(laughing)

title: Iron Man (5/9) Movie CLIP - Is It Safe? (2008) HD

i know it's a movie and all but there is so many things about that magnet

2. how deep is it? from the look of it her hand could have reached to his

3 what's on the bottom of the hole i sounded like it was flesh and if so, 
she must have been touching his heart or lungs witch wouldn't make sense 
thinking of how deep it was
4. the copper wire she pulled out why was it so long and what was it 
attached to?﻿
comments.author: Glenn Kangaji

comments.text:
To answer categorically.
1. No it is positioned above his heart near where his sternum was.
2. It's a few inches into his chest, by normal human standards, but because 
of the tube pushing his ribs a little more open then his original sternum 
did it looks deeper then it is.
3. Most likely the edge of the lining of his thoracic cavity. So the thin 
layer of flesh between the open space in your chest and the muscle, fat, 
and bone around it.
4. That wire was part of an electromagnet that was holding the shrapnel in 
his chest in position so it doesn't tear his heart to shreds any more then 
it already did. The reason it's so long is that electromagnets work by 
wrapping wire around a frame in large groups so you can force electrons to 
flow through it. One wire came loose and unraveled inside him which is why 
it had stretched out so much rather then being all wrapped up like it 
should have been.

comments.text:
This scene really makes Pepper look bad, I'm sorry to say: bad nerves, bad

I don't blame Gwyneth, just bad writing.﻿
comments.author: Nick Hentschel

comments.text:
I'd be concerned with getting it absolutely right, more than anything else: 
performance anxiety, not revulsion.  But my reaction would have been to go 
slower and more carefully, not panic and pull out.
I don't give a damn if that's normal; I'm not like other people, and proud 
of it.
comments.author: Nick Hentschel

comments.text:
Let's face it. If YOU had to put your hand into a hole in your boss's 
chest, wouldn't you be even the slightest bit grossed out?
comments.author: jseeker1867

comments.text:
+Nick Hentschel You're entitled. I don't agree with your interpretation but 
I welcome the chance to examine different perspectives.
comments.author: TheaterPup

comments.text:
I'm not interested in arguing semantics, or in sacrificing principle for 
your idea of "interesting."  This is a bad scene, and indicative of a wider 
sexism.  I dislike it, and i stand by what I've said.
comments.author: Nick Hentschel

comments.text:
+Nick Hentschel I think there's a difference between a flaw, and a 
personality quirk. I mean, do you want Pepper to just be totally cool with 
the arc thing from the beginning. How is that interesting?
comments.author: TheaterPup

comments.text:
Not in my observation.  As you've just pointed out, the point with male 
characters is to get over their flaws.  Women are disproportionately 
advertised *on* them, and this scene is an example.  Therefore, I dislike 
it.
comments.author: Nick Hentschel

comments.text: Men in movies are quite often thought adorable because of their flaws.
comments.author: TheaterPup

comments.text:
No: men are depicted much more positively, as a rule. 
At best, men are expected to overcome their flaws, while women are thought 
adorable *because* of them.  Women are not allowed to improve themselves, 
or they're depicted as somehow being snobs.  This film's writing is a 
classic case in point: Tony grows and changes, while Pepper does not.  And 
for that, he's still supposed to love her.
comments.author: Nick Hentschel

comments.text:
+Nick Hentschel Here's the thing. Men are allowed to be flawed in films. 
That's how characters are able to develop and grow. But women are just 
supposed to be perfect angels? I don't find that nearly as interesting.
comments.author: TheaterPup

comments.text:
+TheaterPup Sadly, that's not my perception of the scene at all.  To me, 
Pepper is just as "clearly" being advertised on her bad qualities, with her 
squeamishness and anxiety being advertised as somehow adorable.
comments.author: Nick Hentschel

comments.text:
+Nick Hentschel Well, characters don't always start with those qualities. 
They have to discover them inside themselves. Tony is introducing Pepper to 
the arc situation and he knows she's nervous. He's clearly playing up the 
danger to prove to Pepper that she CAN handle it if she has to. Tony isn't 
really as outspoken as he appears to be. He finds round about ways of 
expressing things that are important to him.
comments.author: TheaterPup

comments.text:
+TheaterPup Pardon the later response; it's been busy.
I prefer for characters, male or female, to be advertised on the basis of 
their good qualities, not their faults.  I would rather see a character 
like Pepper as desirable for strength, intelligence, and composure, not 
because she's jittery, irrational, and makes the hero look good by 
comparison.
As it stands, only Gwyneth makes the character entertaining; the script 
wouldn't carry a different actress as well.
comments.author: Nick Hentschel

comments.text:
+Nick Hentschel No worries, I didn't expect you to know. Just making a 
point. Meantime, what do you define as "better"? Just curious.
comments.author: TheaterPup

comments.text:
+TheaterPup How should I know?  Nothing in your name or your profile tells 
me what gender you are.  So why would I take it into account?

I stick by what I said: I want to see female characters written better than 
this.
comments.author: Nick Hentschel

comments.text:
+Nick Hentschel So I'm sexist against...myself if I react the way Pepper 
did? As a female I don't need to see women being portrayed as perfect 
goddesses with no personality.
comments.author: TheaterPup

comments.text: +TheaterPup I disagree; it's just sexist.
comments.author: Nick Hentschel

comments.author: Rendersen22

comments.text:
Ok i know this is just a Hollywood film and imagination plays a huge role 
in this movie. And I know it's not real or couldn't possibly be done on a 
person in real life. But how on earth is Tony Starks body functioning with 
the chest reactor? He wouldn't be alive in real life with that thing. I 
studied anatomy and physiology in school, and this movie has always had me 
wondering where exactly is the chest reactor attached to? There should be a 
sternum right under the chest reactor. If there is no sternum, then where 
do the pectoral muscles and ribs attach to? If there is a sternum, then how 
is there a gaping hole in his chest? Lol!! Just a thought. I love this 
movie, but I can't get passed this scene without my anatomy education 
getting in the way. ﻿
comments.author: maharley27

comments.text:
Best guess, the arc reactor powers the electromagnet that keeps the 
shrapnel out of his heart. The new electromagnet replacing the one Pepper 
accidentally removed to early is Tony's artificial sternum. The doctor who 
patched him up at the start did the best he could and attached the lose 
bits to the metal tube in his chest to hold them for the time being, Tony 
replaced that system later with a new electromagnet that fit inside an 
artificial sternum but kept part of the tube for maintenance. Either that 
or the muscle and bone is attached to the tube which would explain why it 
seems to go deeper into his chest then should be biologically possible with 
the tube holding his ribs wider then they should normally be.
comments.author: 6611nitro

I think the role of the reactor is just provide energy for the 
electro-magnet, which keep the bomb shards from "attacking" Tony's heart

lol). Tony's heart is still functioning, as in Ironman 3, after have the

comments.author: MaxPaynefan1

comments.text:
I think the writers should do something in Iron Man 4 (which I really hope 
they are going to do and have Robert D Jr as Iron Man) which means Tony has 
to have the Arc put back in.. (I know the shrapnel prob has been resolved 
but..) maybe he needs an arc as back up for his suits (or that could be the 
excuse for giving him part of his trade-mark back) And I know the arc being 
removed was to mark a new chapter of his life with pepper but hey-This IS 
IRON MAN here, 1&2 were gr8 so keep the style!:)
comments.author: AmbieWolfie

comments.text:
Yeah, I'm kinda torn about removing the arc too. And although I've heard 
that the writers said otherwise, I'd like to think that he injected himself 
with a stabilized version of extremis and that's how he was able to heal. 
But then again, there were probably some major time skips in that epilogue, 
so idk. I'm just happy Tony got a happy ending, which apparently never 
happens in the comics.
comments.author: myfamilyiscrazy

comments.text:
Thanks, I was sure that I was right about that. They magically fixed him in 
Iron Man 3 but I don't know how I feel about Tony not having the reactor. I 
mean, it's like a trademark by now! And shouldn't Tony have like a huge 
gaping hole on his chest? But whatever.
